express_entry.title: Express Entry
express_entry.description: Canada's fastest pathway to permanent residence for skilled workers. Learn about CRS scoring, draw patterns, and application strategies.

guides.title: Express Entry Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: Everything you need to know about Canada's flagship immigration system
guides.overview: Express Entry is Canada's premier immigration system for skilled workers, managing applications for three federal economic immigration programs. Since 2015, it has become the fastest pathway to Canadian permanent residence, with processing times of 6 months or less.

sections.title: What is Express Entry?
sections.content: Express Entry is an online system that manages applications for permanent residence under three federal economic immigration programs: Federal Skilled Worker (FSW), Federal Skilled Trades (FST), and Canadian Experience Class (CEC). Candidates create profiles, receive Comprehensive Ranking System (CRS) scores, and are ranked against each other in the Express Entry pool.

sections.title: How It Works
sections.content:
1. Check your eligibility for one or more Express Entry programs
2. Gather required documents (ECA, language tests, work experience letters)
3. Create your Express Entry profile
4. Receive your CRS score and enter the pool
5. Receive an Invitation to Apply (ITA) if your score is above the cutoff
6. Submit your complete application within 60 days
7. Receive your PR decision (typically within 6 months)

sections.title: CRS Score Factors
sections.content: Your CRS score is calculated based on: Age (max 110 points), Education (max 150 points), Language proficiency (max 160 points), Canadian work experience (max 80 points), Spouse factors (if applicable), Transferability factors, and Additional points for provincial nomination (+600), job offer (+50-200), Canadian education (+15-30), or French proficiency (+25-50).

guides.title: CRS Scoring Deep Dive
guides.subtitle: Understand exactly how your CRS score is calculated
guides.overview: The Comprehensive Ranking System (CRS) is the points-based system used to rank Express Entry candidates. Understanding how each factor contributes to your score is essential for maximizing your chances of receiving an ITA.

sections.title: CRS Score Components
sections.content: Your CRS score (maximum 1,200 points) consists of four main components: Core/Human Capital Factors (up to 500 points for single applicants, 460 for those with a spouse), Spouse Factors (up to 40 points), Skill Transferability Factors (up to 100 points), and Additional Points (up to 600 points for provincial nomination).

sections.title: Age Points
sections.content: Age is worth up to 110 points (single) or 100 points (with spouse). Peak points are awarded between ages 20-29. Points decrease gradually: Age 30 = 105 points, Age 35 = 77 points, Age 40 = 50 points, Age 45+ = 0 points. This makes age one of the few factors you cannot directly improve.

sections.title: Education Points
sections.content: Education is worth up to 150 points (single) or 140 points (with spouse). Points by credential: Secondary diploma (30 points), One-year post-secondary (90 points), Two-year program (98 points), Bachelor's degree or 3+ year program (120 points), Two or more credentials with one 3+ years (128 points), Master's degree (135 points), Doctoral degree (150 points).

sections.title: Language Proficiency Points
sections.content: First official language is worth up to 136 points (single) or 128 points (with spouse). Points per ability at each CLB level: CLB 4-5 = 6 points, CLB 6 = 9 points, CLB 7 = 17 points, CLB 8 = 23 points, CLB 9 = 31 points, CLB 10+ = 34 points. Second official language adds up to 24 points with CLB 5+ in all abilities.

sections.title: Canadian Work Experience Points
sections.content: Canadian work experience (NOC TEER 0, 1, 2, or 3) is worth up to 80 points (single) or 70 points (with spouse). Points breakdown: 1 year = 40 points, 2 years = 53 points, 3 years = 64 points, 4 years = 72 points, 5+ years = 80 points. Must be skilled work in Canada within the last 10 years.

sections.title: Skill Transferability Factors
sections.content: Worth up to 100 points total (max 50 per combination). These combine your education, work experience, and language skills: Education + Language (CLB 7+ with post-secondary = 25-50 points), Education + Canadian Work (13-50 points), Foreign Work + Language (13-50 points), Foreign Work + Canadian Work (13-50 points), Trade Certificate + Language (25-50 points).

sections.title: Additional Points
sections.content: Provincial Nomination: 600 points (guarantees ITA). French proficiency: 25 points (CLB 7+ French with CLB 4 English) or 50 points (CLB 7+ in both). Canadian education: 15 points (1-2 year credential) or 30 points (3+ years). Sibling in Canada (citizen/PR): 15 points. Note: Job offer points were removed as of March 2025.

guides.title: How to Improve Your CRS Score
guides.subtitle: Proven strategies to boost your score and get an ITA faster
guides.overview: If your CRS score is below recent draw cutoffs, there are several proven strategies to improve your ranking. From retaking language tests to gaining Canadian experience, learn the most effective ways to increase your score.

sections.title: Improve Your Language Scores
sections.content: Language proficiency offers the highest point potential. Retake your English test (IELTS, CELPIP, PTE Core) aiming for CLB 9+ in all abilities. Each CLB level above 7 adds significant points: CLB 8 vs CLB 7 is +24 points (6 per ability). CLB 9 vs CLB 8 is +32 points. CLB 10 vs CLB 9 is +12 points. Focus on your weakest ability first.

sections.title: Learn French
sections.content: French proficiency provides major bonus points: 25 points for CLB 7+ French with CLB 4 English, or 50 points for CLB 7+ in both French AND CLB 5+ English. TEF Canada and TCF Canada are the accepted French tests. Even intermediate French (NCLC 5-6) helps you qualify for French category-based draws with lower cutoffs (often 400-435).

sections.title: Get a Provincial Nomination
sections.content: A provincial nomination (PNP) adds 600 CRS points - the single most valuable boost. This virtually guarantees an ITA. Research PNP streams you qualify for: Ontario's Human Capital Priorities, BC PNP Tech, Alberta Express Entry, Saskatchewan SINP. Many provinces don't require job offers for Express Entry-linked streams.

sections.title: Gain Canadian Experience
sections.content: One year of Canadian work experience (NOC TEER 0, 1, 2, or 3) adds 40 points for singles, plus skill transferability bonuses. Options include: working on a PGWP after Canadian studies, getting an employer-specific work permit (LMIA), or working under IEC (Working Holiday). Canadian experience also qualifies you for Canadian Experience Class (CEC) draws.

sections.title: Complete Canadian Education
sections.content: A Canadian credential adds 15-30 points: 15 points for a 1-2 year program, 30 points for 3+ years. It also provides skill transferability points when combined with strong language scores. Consider a 1-year college diploma or graduate certificate in a field related to your occupation. Bonus: This leads to a PGWP for Canadian experience.

sections.title: Leverage Category-Based Draws
sections.content: Since 2023, IRCC conducts targeted draws with lower cutoffs: Healthcare (nurses, doctors, allied health), STEM occupations, Trades (electricians, plumbers, carpenters), French language proficiency, Transport, Agriculture. Check if your NOC code qualifies. French and trades draws have had cutoffs as low as 388-435 vs 500+ for general draws.

guides.title: Category-Based Draws Explained
guides.subtitle: Healthcare, STEM, French, and Trade occupation draws
guides.overview: Since 2023, IRCC has been conducting category-based draws targeting specific occupations and skills. These draws often have significantly lower CRS cutoffs than general draws, making them an excellent opportunity for eligible candidates.

sections.title: What Are Category-Based Draws?
sections.content: Category-based draws are targeted Express Entry rounds that invite candidates based on specific attributes rather than just CRS score. Introduced in 2023, these draws allow IRCC to select candidates who fill labor market gaps in key sectors. Categories include: Healthcare, STEM, Trades, Transport, Agriculture, and French language proficiency.

sections.title: Healthcare Category
sections.content: Healthcare draws target medical professionals. Eligible NOC codes include: 31102 (Family physicians), 31301 (Registered nurses), 31302 (Nurse practitioners), 32101 (Licensed practical nurses), 32120 (Medical laboratory technologists), and many allied health professions. Cutoffs have ranged from 420-480. Must have valid ECA for foreign credentials.

sections.title: STEM Category
sections.content: STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Math) draws target tech workers and engineers. Key NOC codes: 21211 (Data scientists), 21231 (Software engineers), 21232 (Software developers), 21300-21399 (Engineers), 21220 (Cybersecurity specialists). Cutoffs typically 480-520. Valid work experience in STEM field required within last 3 years.

sections.title: Trades Category
sections.content: Trade occupation draws have had some of the lowest cutoffs (388-436). Eligible NOCs include: 72310 (Carpenters), 72400 (Electricians), 72410 (Plumbers), 73200 (Residential installers), 73400 (Heavy equipment operators). Must have 6 months continuous full-time work experience in the trade within last 3 years.

sections.title: French Language Category
sections.content: French proficiency draws have seen the most invitations and lowest cutoffs (379-435). To qualify you need: NCLC 7+ in all four French abilities (speaking, listening, reading, writing). No specific occupation required. French test results (TEF Canada or TCF Canada) must be valid. This is often the easiest category to qualify for.

sections.title: How to Check Your Eligibility
sections.content: 1. Find your NOC code using the NOC Finder tool. 2. Check if your NOC is in the eligible list for any category. 3. Ensure you have qualifying work experience (usually 6 months to 1 year in last 3 years). 4. For French: take TEF or TCF and achieve NCLC 7+. 5. Update your Express Entry profile to reflect qualifying factors. 6. Monitor draw announcements on the IRCC website.

study_permit.title: Study in Canada
study_permit.description: Complete guides to studying in Canada, from application to post-graduation work permits and pathways to permanent residence.

guides.title: Study Permit Application Guide
guides.subtitle: Step-by-step guide to applying for your Canadian study permit
guides.overview: A study permit allows you to study at a designated learning institution (DLI) in Canada. This comprehensive guide covers eligibility, required documents, application process, and tips for approval.

sections.title: Study Permit Basics
sections.content: A study permit is a document that allows foreign nationals to study at a Designated Learning Institution (DLI) in Canada. It is NOT a visa - you may also need a visitor visa or eTA to enter Canada. Study permits are typically valid for the length of your program plus 90 days. You can work up to 20 hours/week during academic sessions and full-time during scheduled breaks.

sections.title: Eligibility Requirements
sections.content: To qualify for a study permit you must: 1) Have an acceptance letter from a DLI, 2) Prove you have enough money to pay tuition, living expenses, and return transportation (approximately CAD $20,635/year for living expenses outside Quebec), 3) Be a law-abiding citizen with no criminal record, 4) Be in good health (may require medical exam), 5) Convince an officer you will leave Canada when your permit expires.

sections.title: Required Documents
sections.content: Standard documents include: Valid passport, Acceptance letter from a DLI, Proof of financial support (bank statements, GIC, scholarship letters, sponsor letters), Letter of explanation stating your purpose and ties to home country, Provincial Attestation Letter (PAL) for most provinces since 2024, Passport-size photos meeting IRCC specifications, Language test results (if required), and Police clearance certificates.

sections.title: Provincial Attestation Letter (PAL)
sections.content: Since January 2024, most study permit applications require a Provincial Attestation Letter (PAL). This letter confirms your province/territory has allocated a spot for you within their international student cap. Each province has its own PAL issuance process - typically provided by your DLI after you accept your offer. Exemptions include master's, doctoral, and some K-12 programs.

sections.title: Application Process
sections.content: 1) Get accepted to a DLI and obtain PAL, 2) Gather all required documents, 3) Create an IRCC account online, 4) Complete the application forms (IMM 1294), 5) Pay the fees ($150 CAD processing + $85 biometrics), 6) Submit biometrics at a VAC or ASC within 30 days, 7) Wait for processing (varies by country, typically 4-12 weeks), 8) If approved, travel to Canada and obtain your permit at the port of entry.

sections.title: Tips for Approval
sections.content: Show strong ties to your home country (property, job, family). Explain why you chose Canada and this specific program. Demonstrate sufficient funds that are readily accessible. Choose a program aligned with your past education/career. Avoid previously refused applications or overstays. Submit complete documentation the first time. Consider applying from countries with higher approval rates if you have legal status there.

guides.title: Choosing the Right DLI
guides.subtitle: How to select a Designated Learning Institution
guides.overview: Not all Canadian schools qualify you for a study permit or post-graduation work permit. Learn how to verify DLI status and choose programs that support your immigration goals.

guides.title: Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP)
guides.subtitle: Work in Canada after your studies
guides.overview: The PGWP allows you to work in Canada for up to 3 years after graduation. Learn about eligibility requirements, application timing, and how it leads to permanent residence.

sections.title: PGWP Basics
sections.content: The Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP) is an open work permit allowing international graduates from eligible Canadian Designated Learning Institutions (DLIs) to work for any employer in Canada. It's a crucial stepping stone to permanent residence through Canadian Experience Class (CEC) or Provincial Nominee Programs.

sections.title: Eligibility Requirements
sections.content: To qualify you must: Graduate from a PGWP-eligible DLI, Complete a program of at least 8 months, Have maintained full-time student status during your program, Apply within 180 days of receiving your final marks/completion letter. Programs must be degree, diploma, or certificate programs (not ESL, distance learning, or non-DLI programs).

sections.title: PGWP Duration
sections.content: PGWP validity depends on your program length: 8-month to 2-year programs = PGWP equal to program length. Programs 2+ years = 3-year PGWP. Multiple programs can be combined if completed back-to-back at same DLI. Example: 1-year diploma = 1-year PGWP. 2-year diploma = 3-year PGWP. 4-year degree = 3-year PGWP (max).

sections.title: Application Process
sections.content: 1) Receive your final transcript and completion letter, 2) Apply online within 180 days of completing your program, 3) Pay the $255 fee ($155 work permit + $100 open work permit holder fee), 4) Maintain valid status while application is processing (implied status allows you to work). Processing time: typically 80-120 days. You can work full-time while waiting.

sections.title: PGWP to PR Pathway
sections.content: Use your PGWP wisely: Work in a NOC TEER 0, 1, 2, or 3 occupation to qualify for CEC. Accumulate 1 year of skilled Canadian work experience for Express Entry. Achieve CLB 7+ language scores while working. Consider PNP programs that target international graduates. Many provinces have dedicated streams for PGWP holders with job offers.

sections.title: Important Restrictions
sections.content: PGWP cannot be extended or renewed. If your PGWP expires before getting PR, consider: Bridging Open Work Permit (if you have AOR for PR), Employer-specific work permit (requires LMIA), Study permit (enroll in another program). Plan your PR application timeline carefully to avoid gaps.

guides.title: Student to PR Pathway
guides.subtitle: Your complete roadmap from student to permanent resident
guides.overview: The student pathway is one of the most popular routes to Canadian PR. Learn how to maximize your chances by choosing the right program, province, and gaining Canadian experience.

guides.title: Student Direct Stream (SDS)
guides.subtitle: Faster study permit processing for eligible countries
guides.overview: The Student Direct Stream offers faster processing (typically 20 days) for applicants from eligible countries who meet specific requirements. Learn if you qualify and how to apply.

work_permit.title: Work Permits
work_permit.description: Understand the different types of Canadian work permits, from LMIA-based permits to open work permits and LMIA-exempt categories.

guides.title: Work Permit Overview
guides.subtitle: Understanding Canadian work permit categories
guides.overview: Canadian work permits come in many forms: LMIA-based, LMIA-exempt, open, and employer-specific. This guide helps you understand which type applies to your situation.

sections.title: Types of Work Permits
sections.content: There are two main categories: Employer-Specific Work Permits (tied to one employer, job, and location) and Open Work Permits (work for any employer anywhere in Canada). Employer-specific permits may require an LMIA or qualify for LMIA exemption. Open work permits are available through specific programs like PGWP, spousal permits, or bridging permits.

sections.title: LMIA-Based Work Permits
sections.content: Labour Market Impact Assessment (LMIA) work permits require your employer to first obtain an LMIA from Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC). This proves hiring a foreign worker won't negatively impact Canadian workers. The LMIA process takes 2-3 months and costs $1,000 per position. A positive LMIA adds 50-200 points to your CRS score for Express Entry.

sections.title: LMIA-Exempt Work Permits
sections.content: Many work permits don't require an LMIA under international agreements or specific programs: CUSMA/NAFTA professionals, Intra-Company Transfers (ICT), International Experience Canada (IEC), Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP), Spousal Open Work Permits, Significant benefit to Canada (researchers, academics). These use LMIA exemption codes (e.g., R205, R204).

sections.title: Open Work Permits
sections.content: Open work permits let you work for any employer. Categories include: Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP) for DLI graduates, Spousal/Common-law Partner OWP for spouses of skilled workers or students, Bridging OWP while waiting for PR, Vulnerable Worker OWP, and specific humanitarian programs. Most valuable for gaining Canadian experience for Express Entry.

sections.title: Application Process
sections.content: 1) Determine your eligibility category, 2) Gather employer documents (job offer, LMIA if needed, or exemption code), 3) Gather personal documents (passport, photo, proof of status), 4) Apply online via IRCC portal, 5) Pay fees ($155 work permit + $85 biometrics), 6) Submit biometrics within 30 days, 7) Wait for processing (varies 2-16 weeks by country), 8) Receive work permit at port of entry or by mail if inside Canada.

sections.title: Work Permit Duration
sections.content: Employer-specific permits are usually valid for the job offer duration (max 2-3 years). PGWP validity matches your program length (8 months to 3 years). IEC permits are typically 12-24 months depending on country. Spousal OWPs match the principal applicant's permit. All permits can potentially be renewed or extended if you remain eligible.

guides.title: LMIA Work Permits
guides.subtitle: Employer-sponsored work permits with Labour Market Impact Assessment
guides.overview: An LMIA is a document that a Canadian employer may need to obtain before hiring a foreign worker. Learn about the LMIA process, exemptions, and how it affects your work permit.

guides.title: Open Work Permits
guides.subtitle: Work for any employer in Canada
guides.overview: Open work permits allow you to work for any Canadian employer without needing a specific job offer. Learn about eligibility categories including spouse permits, bridging permits, and PGWP.

guides.title: International Experience Canada (IEC)
guides.subtitle: Working Holiday, Young Professionals, and Co-op programs
guides.overview: IEC allows young people from partner countries to work and travel in Canada. Learn about the three categories, eligibility requirements, and how to apply.

sections.title: IEC Categories
sections.content: There are 3 IEC categories: 1) Working Holiday - open work permit, no job offer needed, work for any employer. 2) Young Professionals - employer-specific permit, need job offer in your field of study. 3) International Co-op - for students doing internship as part of studies, need job offer. Availability varies by country agreement.

sections.title: Eligibility Requirements
sections.content: General requirements: Citizen of a participating country, typically 18-30 or 18-35 (varies by country), have a valid passport, have health insurance, have enough money for initial expenses (~$2,500 CAD), no criminal record, never participated in same IEC category before. Country-specific requirements may apply.

sections.title: Participating Countries
sections.content: 35+ countries have IEC agreements with Canada including: UK, Ireland, France, Germany, Australia, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and many more. Age limits and quotas vary by country. For example: UK (18-30, ~10,000 spots), France (18-35, ~14,000 spots), Australia (18-30, unlimited). Check IRCC for your country's specific terms.

sections.title: Application Process
sections.content: 1) Create IEC profile during the seasonal round (usually November-April), 2) Enter pool(s) for your eligible categories, 3) If drawn, receive Invitation to Apply (ITA) via lottery, 4) Accept ITA and submit full application within 10 days, 5) Pay fees ($156 participation + $100 OWP holder fee + $85 biometrics), 6) Submit biometrics, 7) Receive Port of Entry letter, 8) Activate work permit within 12 months at Canadian border.

sections.title: IEC to PR Pathway
sections.content: IEC is excellent for gaining Canadian work experience for Express Entry: Work 1 year in skilled occupation (NOC TEER 0/1/2/3) to qualify for CEC. Use your time in Canada to improve language scores. Network and find an employer for PNP nomination. Some provinces have streams specifically for workers with Canadian experience. Plan your PR strategy from day one.

sections.title: Tips for Getting Selected
sections.content: Apply early when rounds open (competition increases throughout the season). Check your profile regularly for ITAs (10-day deadline to accept). Some countries have multiple draws - stay in the pool if not selected initially. Have documents ready before applying (police certificate takes time). Consider less popular categories (Young Professionals often has more spots than Working Holiday).

guides.title: Intra-Company Transfers (ICT)
guides.subtitle: For multinational company employees
guides.overview: ICT work permits allow employees of multinational companies to transfer to Canadian branches. Learn about the eligibility requirements and application process.

credentials.title: Credential Evaluation
credentials.description: Educational Credential Assessment (ECA) guides for Express Entry and professional licensing in Canada.

guides.title: WES ECA Guide
guides.subtitle: Step-by-step World Education Services credential evaluation
guides.overview: WES is the most popular credential evaluation service for Express Entry. This guide covers the application process, document requirements, and expected timelines.

sections.title: What is WES ECA?
sections.content: World Education Services (WES) is a designated organization that evaluates foreign educational credentials against Canadian standards. An ECA report from WES is required for Express Entry to prove your education level. The report compares your degree to a Canadian equivalent (e.g., foreign bachelor's = Canadian bachelor's degree).

sections.title: Application Process
sections.content: 1) Create a WES account at wes.org/ca, 2) Select 'ECA Application for IRCC', 3) Enter your education details and pay fees, 4) Receive your WES reference number, 5) Request your institution to send documents directly to WES, 6) WES reviews documents and issues report (7-20 business days after receiving all documents).

sections.title: Required Documents
sections.content: Documents must be sent directly from your institution to WES: Official transcripts (sealed), Degree certificate/diploma, Credential verification form (for some countries). For India: transcripts via WES-approved agencies. For China: verification through CHESICC/CDGDC. For Philippines: send through WES-approved courier. Check WES country requirements for your specific case.

sections.title: Fees and Timeline
sections.content: WES fees: CAD $220 (ECA for IRCC) + document handling fees. Processing time: 7-20 business days after WES receives all documents. Total timeline typically 4-8 weeks including document delivery. Express evaluation available for additional fee. ECA report is valid for 5 years from issue date.

sections.title: Country-Specific Requirements
sections.content: India: Use WES Gateway or authorized agents like DataFlow. China: Academic records through CHESICC, degree through CDGDC. Philippines: Red ribbon apostille required. Pakistan: HEC verification required. Nigeria: Transcripts via school directly. Most countries: sealed transcripts sent directly from institution. Always check WES Required Documents tool for your country.

sections.title: Tips for Success
sections.content: Start early - the process can take 2+ months. Request extra official transcript copies from your institution. Track your documents using WES online portal. Ensure your name matches across all documents and passport. If you have multiple degrees, you may only need ECA for your highest credential. Contact WES support if documents are delayed.

guides.title: IELTS General Training Guide
guides.subtitle: Prepare for the IELTS test for Canadian immigration
guides.overview: IELTS General Training is one of the most popular English tests for Canadian immigration. Learn about the test format, scoring, and how it converts to CLB levels.

sections.title: IELTS for Immigration
sections.content: For Canadian immigration, you need IELTS General Training (NOT Academic). Results are valid for 2 years from the test date. The test measures four abilities: Listening (30 min), Reading (60 min), Writing (60 min), and Speaking (11-14 min). You receive band scores from 0-9 for each ability, which convert to Canadian Language Benchmark (CLB) levels.

sections.title: CLB Conversion Chart
sections.content: IELTS to CLB conversion: Listening - 4.5=CLB4, 5.0=CLB5, 5.5=CLB6, 6.0=CLB7, 7.5=CLB8, 8.0=CLB9, 8.5=CLB10. Reading - 3.5=CLB4, 4.0=CLB5, 5.0=CLB6, 6.0=CLB7, 6.5=CLB8, 7.0=CLB9, 8.0=CLB10. Writing - 4.0=CLB4, 5.0=CLB5, 5.5=CLB6, 6.0=CLB7, 6.5=CLB8, 7.0=CLB9, 7.5=CLB10. Speaking - 4.0=CLB4, 5.0=CLB5, 5.5=CLB6, 6.0=CLB7, 6.5=CLB8, 7.0=CLB9, 7.5=CLB10.

sections.title: Test Format
sections.content: Listening: 4 sections, 40 questions, recordings of native speakers. Reading: 3 sections, 40 questions, texts from books, magazines, newspapers. Writing: Task 1 (150 words minimum) - write a letter; Task 2 (250 words minimum) - essay responding to a point of view. Speaking: Face-to-face interview in 3 parts (introduction, long turn, discussion).

sections.title: Target Scores for Immigration
sections.content: Express Entry minimum: CLB 7 for FSW (IELTS 6.0 in each). CEC and PNP often require CLB 5-7 depending on NOC level. For maximum CRS points, aim for CLB 9+ (IELTS 7.0+ Reading, 8.0+ Listening, 7.0+ Writing/Speaking). Each CLB level above 7 significantly increases your score. CLB 9 in all abilities = 124 points vs 68 points at CLB 7.

sections.title: Test Booking and Cost
sections.content: IELTS costs approximately CAD $310-350 depending on location. Book online through British Council, IDP, or local test centers. Book 2-4 weeks in advance as popular dates fill quickly. Results available online after 13 days (paper-based) or 5-7 days (computer-delivered). You can send results directly to IRCC electronically.

sections.title: Preparation Tips
sections.content: Practice with official Cambridge IELTS books. Take timed practice tests to build stamina. For Listening: practice note-taking and predicting answers. For Reading: skim and scan techniques, time management (20 min per section). For Writing: learn essay structures, use formal language, address all parts of the task. For Speaking: practice fluency over perfection, expand your answers, use idioms naturally.

guides.title: CELPIP General Guide
guides.subtitle: Canadian English Language Proficiency Index Program
guides.overview: CELPIP is a Canadian English test taken entirely on computer. Learn about the test format, advantages, and preparation strategies.

sections.title: Why Choose CELPIP?
sections.content: CELPIP (Canadian English Language Proficiency Index Program) is developed by Paragon Testing and is 100% Canadian. Advantages: Entirely computer-based (including speaking), uses Canadian accents and contexts, faster results (8 calendar days online), one sitting (~3 hours), accepted for both Express Entry and citizenship. Results valid for 2 years.

sections.title: Test Format
sections.content: CELPIP-General has 4 components: Listening (47-55 min) - 6 parts, 38 questions. Reading (55-60 min) - 4 parts. Writing (53-60 min) - 2 tasks (email and responding to survey/opinion). Speaking (15-20 min) - 8 tasks recorded on computer. Total test time: approximately 3 hours in one sitting.

sections.title: Scoring and CLB Conversion
sections.content: CELPIP scores range from M (minimal) to 12. Direct CLB conversion: CELPIP 4=CLB4, CELPIP 5=CLB5, CELPIP 6=CLB6, CELPIP 7=CLB7, CELPIP 8=CLB8, CELPIP 9=CLB9, CELPIP 10+=CLB10. Unlike IELTS, CELPIP scores map directly to CLB levels (e.g., CELPIP 9 = CLB 9, not requiring band interpretation).

sections.title: Test Locations and Cost
sections.content: CELPIP is available at test centers across Canada and in some international locations (UAE, Philippines, India, China). Test fee: CAD $280-320 depending on location. Book through celpip.ca. Test dates available weekly in major Canadian cities. Results available online in 8 calendar days and can be sent directly to IRCC.

sections.title: CELPIP vs IELTS
sections.content: Choose CELPIP if: You prefer computer-based testing, want faster results, are comfortable with Canadian accents, prefer speaking to a computer vs examiner. Choose IELTS if: You prefer paper-based tests, want face-to-face speaking, need results accepted in other countries. Both are equally accepted by IRCC.

sections.title: Preparation Strategies
sections.content: Use official CELPIP practice tests at celpip.ca. Practice typing for writing section (you type responses). Get comfortable speaking into a microphone (no human interaction). Practice with timer - strict time limits per task. Focus on Canadian spelling and expressions. Free preparation resources available on CELPIP website including sample questions and webinars.

guides.title: Spousal Sponsorship Guide
guides.subtitle: Sponsor your spouse or common-law partner for PR
guides.overview: Spousal sponsorship allows Canadian citizens and permanent residents to sponsor their spouse, common-law partner, or conjugal partner for permanent residence. Learn about inland vs outland applications.

sections.title: Who Can Sponsor
sections.content: You can sponsor if you are: A Canadian citizen or permanent resident, at least 18 years old, and can prove you can support your spouse financially. You cannot sponsor if: you are on social assistance (except disability), you have an unremoved deportation order, you are in prison, you were sponsored as a spouse yourself and became PR less than 5 years ago, or you are in default on family support obligations.

sections.title: Who Can Be Sponsored
sections.content: You can sponsor your: Spouse (legally married), Common-law partner (lived together in conjugal relationship for at least 12 continuous months), or Conjugal partner (in committed relationship for 1+ year but could not live together or marry due to immigration barriers or persecution). Your partner must be 18 or older. Same-sex relationships are recognized.

sections.title: Inland vs Outland Applications
sections.content: Inland: Sponsored person is already in Canada with valid status. Can apply for Open Work Permit while waiting (usually granted in ~4 months). Cannot leave Canada while processing without abandoning application. Processing time: ~12-15 months. Outland: Sponsored person is outside Canada. They continue living abroad during processing. Can visit Canada on visitor visa. Processing time: ~12-24 months depending on country.

sections.title: Required Documents
sections.content: Key documents include: Proof of sponsor's status (citizenship or PR card), Marriage certificate or proof of common-law relationship, Relationship history and photos together, Joint financial documents (lease, bank accounts, bills), Communication history (messages, call logs), Forms: IMM 1344, IMM 0008, IMM 5669, IMM 5406, IMM 5532. Police certificates from all countries lived in 6+ months since age 18.

sections.title: Processing Times and Fees
sections.content: Current processing time: 12-15 months (inland), 12-24 months (outland). Fees: $1,080 sponsorship fee + $500 PR processing fee + $85 biometrics + $500 RPRF (Right of Permanent Residence Fee) = ~$2,165 total. Additional fees may apply for translations, police certificates, and medical exams.

sections.title: Proving Genuine Relationship
sections.content: IRCC looks for evidence your relationship is genuine: Photos together over time (dates, occasions), Joint financial commitments (lease, bills, accounts), Travel together, Communication records, Wedding photos/video, Affidavits from friends/family. Red flags include: large age gaps, no common language, brief courtship, financial incentives, inconsistent interview answers.

guides.title: Parents and Grandparents Program (PGP)
guides.subtitle: Sponsor your parents or grandparents for PR
guides.overview: The PGP allows Canadian citizens and permanent residents to sponsor their parents and grandparents. Learn about the lottery system, income requirements, and Super Visa alternatives.

sections.title: How PGP Works
sections.content: The Parents and Grandparents Program uses an interest-to-sponsor intake system. Each year, IRCC invites potential sponsors to submit interest forms during a limited window (usually October). Invitations to apply are sent randomly to selected sponsors. Limited spots available (~15,000-25,000 per year), making this highly competitive.

sections.title: Sponsor Eligibility
sections.content: To sponsor parents/grandparents you must: Be a Canadian citizen or permanent resident, Be at least 18 years old, Live in Canada, Meet minimum income requirements for 3 consecutive tax years, Sign an undertaking to support your parents for 20 years. You cannot sponsor if you received social assistance (except disability) or defaulted on previous sponsorship.

sections.title: Minimum Income Requirements
sections.content: You must meet LICO+ (Low Income Cut-Off + 30%) for 3 consecutive years. 2024 requirements (example): 2 people household = $43,082, 3 people = $52,965, 4 people = $64,306, 5 people = $72,927. Income can include employment, self-employment, and EI. Does NOT include social assistance or provincial child benefits. Spouse's income can be combined if they co-sign.

sections.title: Application Process
sections.content: 1) Submit interest-to-sponsor form during intake period, 2) If selected, receive Invitation to Apply (ITA), 3) Submit complete application within 60 days of ITA, 4) Provide income proof (NOAs for 3 years), 5) Parents complete medical exams and police certificates, 6) Processing takes 20-36 months. Your parents cannot work or access healthcare until PR is granted.

sections.title: Super Visa Alternative
sections.content: If not selected for PGP, consider Super Visa: Valid for up to 10 years, allows stays of up to 5 years per visit, parents can visit without PR status. Requirements: Valid medical insurance, sponsor's proof of income (1 year only), letter of invitation. Super Visa holders cannot work in Canada but can visit for extended periods.

sections.title: Tips for Success
sections.content: Submit interest form immediately when intake opens (first-come basis in some years). Keep 3 years of tax returns and NOAs ready. Consider increasing income before applying if below threshold. Have backup plan (Super Visa) while waiting. Processing is lengthy - start when parents are still healthy enough for medical exam. Maintain communication with IRCC through your account.
